awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Ceramics as a Chronological Indicator
awd_abstract_narration:
Mannat Johal, a PhD scholar at the University of Chicago, will investigate how people and societies experience time through their participation in everyday activities of production and consumption. While time is generally understood in terms of quantifiable units such as hours, days, months and years, recent scholarship has highlighted that human experiences of time are diverse, and rooted in activities rather than objective measurements. As a discipline that tracks long-term processes of continuity and change, archaeology is particularly well-suited to tracing the rhythms and durations of a range of activities, everyday acts of cooking and consumption as well as events like death and commemoration. Further, archaeological studies emphasize how relationships between people and the material world - landscapes, monuments and objects - influence how people and societies form a sense of history, and develop their collective memory. These complex experiences of time have been significant historically and remain important in today's world, as seen in disputed claims to heritage, debates over the repatriation of museum objects, and a widespread interest in documenting and preserving traditional practices. Researchers collaborate with scholars and government officials in India to train students and produce knowledge about the past that is disseminated to both academic and non-academic audiences. Additionally, this team of researchers will collaborate with local authorities to create a museum with finds excavated at Maski.

Shifting the focus from meaningful monuments to the sphere of everyday life, the research will study how the production and use of ceramic vessels shaped the rhythms of household activities in medieval south India. Ceramic vessels were common objects accessible to a wide range of the population and used for a variety of purposes, such as cooking, storage, eating, and transporting goods. Working with a team of excavators at Maski, located in the semi-arid southern reaches of India's Deccan plateau, the researcher will study how ceramic vessel forms shifted over time, and the ways in which potters created vessels that may have been considered "traditional" or "novel." She will combine evidence from typological analysis with data on ceramic pastes to assess how potters created vessels with varying levels of durability. This research is part of a larger effort to develop a historical archaeology of the Indian Subcontinent.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of this NSF award, I conducted archaeological excavations and ceramic analysis in India. Following a first season of excavations at a medieval settlement – a large village occupied during the 12th-14th century AD – at Maski (South India), I analyzed ceramics from two distinct spatial contexts in the site. These were: 1) a house with rammed-mud walls and several layers of periodically resurfaced plaster floors, and 2) a masonry-lined well associated with informal outdoor surfaces. During a second season of excavation (supported by the NSF), salvage excavations were conducted at another medieval site at Maski – a large walled settlement extending across multiple terraces of an outcrop, and with significant architectural remains. Excavations at one of the lower occupied terraces of this site, where modern construction activities had exposed archaeological contexts, revealed a stratified deposit of discard. Used during the late-13th and early-14th century AD and, in a previous phase, during the 12th century BC, this midden contained the refuse of several domestic structures located nearby.

Ceramic analyses from these three lived and frequented spaces, where people conducted everyday activities such as cooking, eating, collecting their daily supply of water, etc., reveal interesting patterns. In the first place, it is apparent that potters operating at Maski during the 12th-14th centuries AD used a variety of production techniques, bringing together older and newer elements in the local tradition of ceramic-making. Results of ceramic petrography – a form of mineralogical analysis that shows the composition of the paste – suggest that potters adjusted pastes and morphology for different kinds of vessels; these adjustments would in turn affect the durability and fragility of vessels and shape how users contended with differential rates of breakage. Residents of these settlements used vessels of different forms for various activities, as the distributions of ceramics in these three contexts demonstrate. Lastly, patterns of deposition at these three activity-spaces show that the rhythms of maintenance and discard – such as regularly clearing the floor of the house, and letting discard accumulate in an outdoor public space such as the area around the well – significantly shapes the ceramic assemblage that archaeologists recover.

The research conducted has implications for South Asia’s historical archaeology, and speaks to wider disciplinary debates in both History and Anthropology. Presenting data on the first medieval ceramics excavated from stratigraphically secure contexts in the region, this research contributes empirically to the historical archaeology of the Indian Subcontinent. It is also in dialogue with the large body of scholarship on premodern India that grapples with questions of historical consciousness and collective memory. Drawing upon monumental architecture, royal epigraphy and courtly texts, scholars of precolonial India have documented narratives about collective memory and identity formation through which actors – typically political elites – related to “the past in the past”. My research shifts the focus to quotidian tasks performed in non-elite spaces, investigating how individuals and communities oriented themselves in time, drawing upon available pasts and anticipating futures in their everyday engagements with materials. Furthermore, proposing a series of concrete relationships between ceramic vessels and time that are rooted in everyday activities, this research problematizes the widespread tendency to treat ceramics as indicators of chronology.
